questions.text: A patient who is a known case of Crohn's disease underwent terminal ileal resection for the presence of stricture. Several months later, he presents to the clinic with a history of a tingling sensation of hands and the peripheral smear shows the presence of macrocytic anemia. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

Option B:

 

The most likely cause of tingling sensation in the hands and macrocytic anemia following ileal resection is vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

This is the correct answer. The terminal ileum is the site for vitamin B12 absorption. Resection of this part of the bowel can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency, which may result in neurological symptoms like tingling and macrocytic anemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency can cause neurological and cardiac symptoms, but it is not typically associated with macrocytic anemia.

 

Option C: While folic acid deficiency can cause macrocytic anemia, it doesn't typically cause the neurological symptoms described and is more often linked to dietary deficiencies or malabsorption syndromes not specific to the terminal ileum.

 

Option D: Calcium deficiency can lead to neuromuscular irritability and osteoporosis but is not typically associated with macrocytic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following resection of the terminal ileum, a patient may develop vitamin B12 deficiency due to the loss of specific receptors located there, which can lead to macrocytic anemia and neurological symptoms like paresthesias.

 

  • The absorption of bile salts and vitamin B12 only occurs in the terminal ileum, where there are specific transporters.
  • If the jejunum is resected, the ileum can assume all the required absorptive functions.
  • Resection of the terminal ileum will result in a diminished bile salt pool, and vitamin B12 deficiency and may lead to deficiency of the fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. pg 1307

choices.text: Jejunum has a wider lumen and longer vasa recta
Ileum is usually 60% of the total small bowel length
Ligament of Treitz marks DJ flexure
Ileal resections are better tolerated than jejunal resections

questions.text: Which of these is a false statement about small bowel anatomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ileal resections are better tolerated than jejunal resections.

 

Option D:

 

This statement is false. Ileal resections are less well-tolerated than jejunal resections due to the ileum's unique role in the absorption of bile salts, vitamin B12, and its contribution to water absorption. Significant resection of the ileum can lead to bile salt pool reduction, vitamin B12 deficiency, and potential deficiencies in fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K), as well as problematic diarrhea due to less effective water absorption.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: This statement is true. The jejunum typically has a wider lumen and longer vasa recta when compared to the ileum.

 

Option B: This is also true. The ileum is generally around 60% of the total small bowel length.

 

Option C: True. The ligament of Treitz is an anatomical landmark indicating the location where the duodenum transitions to the jejunum, also known as the duodenojejunal (DJ) flexure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the anatomy and physiology of the small intestine, the ileum's unique absorptive roles make ileal resections less well-tolerated than jejunal resections.

 

  • Total length - 350-800 cm
  • Jejunum - 40%, wider lumen, longer vasa recta
  • Ileum - 60%, thicker mesentery, branched vasa recta
  • The jejunum is the principal site for digestion and absorption of fluid, electrolytes, iron, folate, fat, protein and carbohydrate.
  • The ileum also plays an important role in water absorption, possibly because the tightness of the intercellular junctions supports a concentration gradient across its lumen. Significant ileal resection therefore commonly results in very troublesome Diarrhoea.

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1306-07

choices.text: Caecum and appendix lie on the left
Surgery is done for acute intestinal obstruction
Appendicectomy is done even if appendix is normal
During surgery, caecum is fixed to the right

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy with a history of failure to thrive during infancy was brought to the casualty with fever, abdominal pain with distension, and bilious vomiting for 20 days. Which of these is incorrect about midgut malrotation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) During surgery, caecum is fixed to the right

 

Option D:

 

This is incorrect. In the Ladd's procedure for the correction of midgut malrotation, the cecum is not fixed to the right side of the abdomen. The aim is to widen the mesenteric base and place the small bowel on the right and the colon on the left, without any fixation, to prevent future volvulus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: This is correct. In cases of midgut malrotation, the cecum and appendix are often located on the left due to abnormal rotation and fixation of the intestines.

 

Option B: Correct. Acute intestinal obstruction in midgut malrotation leading to volvulus is a surgical emergency and requires prompt intervention to prevent complications like ischemic damage to the intestines.

 

Option C: Correct. An incidental appendectomy is typically performed during surgery for midgut malrotation to prevent future diagnostic confusion since the appendix may not be located in its usual position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The surgery, known as Ladd's procedure, involves detorsion if volvulus is present, division of Ladd's bands, broadening of the mesentery, incidental appendectomy, and placement of the small bowel on the right and the colon on the left to prevent future volvulus.

 

  • Malrotated midgut: Entire small bowel lies on right, caecum in epigastrium and colon on left. Ladd’s band attached cecum to right abdominal wall and cause duodenal compression.
  • Malrotation can be asymptomatic or may be manifested as chronic abdominal pain, with bilious vomiting and failure to thrive.
  • Mid-gut malrotation may get complicated by twist/volvulus of small bowel leading to acute intestinal obstruction.
  • Typical finding of midgut volvulus - acute onset of bilious vomiting.
  • An acute small bowel volvulus suspected in an acidotic baby, vomiting bile with a gasless abdominal radiograph and a scaphoid abdomen demands an immediate laparotomy.
  • Well babies presenting with bilious vomiting have a contrast study to locate the DJ flexure. If the DJ flexure lies to the left of the vertebral column, at the level of the pylorus, the mesentery is likely to be stable. At operation, the bowel is placed in the non-rotated position and the mesentery is broadened – Ladd’s procedure.
  • Surgery – Ladd’s procedure

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition, pg 267

questions.text: The most common site for intestinal tuberculosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Distal ileum

 

Option A:

 

The most common site of intestinal tuberculosis is the distal ileum and cecum.

 

This is correct. The distal ileum is the most common site for intestinal tuberculosis because it has an abundance of lymphoid tissue, which is conducive to the settlement and multiplication of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intestinal tuberculosis most commonly affects the ileocecal region and may present with a variety of symptoms including abdominal pain, weight loss, and fever. The disease can manifest in two forms, ulcerative and hyperplastic, with the ulcerative form often being secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

  • Ulcerative tuberculosis develops secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis and arises as a result of swallowing tubercle bacilli. Multiple ulcers, lying transversely, develop in the terminal ileum and the overlying serosa is thickened, reddened and covered in tubercles.

  • Hyperplastic is caused by the ingestion of Mycobacterium tuberculosis by patients with a high resistance to the organism. The infection usually occurs in the ileocecal region, although solitary and multiple lesions in the distal ileum are also sometimes seen.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1308

questions.text:
A 26-year-old female patient present with attacks of abdominal pain and intermittent diarrhea. There is steatorrhea, anemia and loss of weight. Patient also has a mass in the right iliac fossa. A barium study shows the following:

 

 

What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ileocecal TB

 

Option C:

 

The probable diagnosis for a patient presenting with abdominal pain, intermittent diarrhea, steatorrhea, anemia, weight loss, and a right iliac fossa mass, supported by a barium study showing a pulled-up cecum, is ileocecal tuberculosis (TB).

 

Ileocecal TB is the most likely diagnosis due to the combination of systemic symptoms, a palpable mass, and characteristic findings on imaging, such as the string sign of Kantor (narrowing of the terminal ileum), thickening, and gaping of the ileocecal valve, and thickening and hypermotility of the cecum).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Appendix carcinoid typically does not present with the systemic symptoms described or the specific radiologic findings seen in this barium study.

 

Option B: Amebic typhlitis may cause similar symptoms but would not typically result in the pulled-up cecum seen on the barium study.

 

Option D: Ulcerative colitis usually involves the colon and would not typically present with a pulled-up cecum, or the systemic symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ileocecal TB is characterized by systemic symptoms like weight loss and anemia, local findings such as a mass in the right iliac fossa, and specific radiologic signs in the barium study indicative of TB involvement in the ileocecal region.

 

  • Patients usually present with attacks of abdominal pain and intermittent diarrhea. There is incomplete ileal obstruction, leading to stasis and bacterial overgrowth. This in turn causes steatorrhea, anemia and loss of weight.

  • Patients may present with a mass in the right iliac fossa and vague ill health. The differential diagnosis is that of an appendix mass, lymphoma, carcinoma of the caecum, CD, tuberculosis or actinomycosis.

  • A barium follow-through or small bowel enema will show a long narrow filling defect in the terminal ileum (which may result in a differential diagnosis of CD). CT will also demonstrate the narrowed segment with proximal distension and the associated lymphadenopathy.

 

Barium study

 

1. Acute-to-subacute stage

 

  • Narrowing of the terminal ileum (string sign of Kantor)

  • Thickening and gaping of the ileocecal valve

  • Thickening and hypermotility of the caecum

 

2. Chronic stage

 

  • Ileo-cecal valve appears fixed, rigid and incompetent.

  • caecum appears conical in shape and shrunken in size.

  • Pulled-up caecum (away from the right iliac fossa) due to fibrotic changes in the mesocolon.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th ed., pg 1308

Online article: https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-27606

choices.text: Diarrhoea is an early symptom
Perianal disease is characterized by multiple fistulae in ano
c-ASCA and fecal calprotectin are elevated

questions.text: All of these findings are common to both intestinal TB and Crohn’s disease, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) C-ASCA and Fecal Calprotectin are elevated

 

Option D:

 

c-ASCA is an antibody elevated in Crohn's disease but not in TB. Fecal calprotectin is a marker of intestinal inflammation typically elevated in inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn's disease. It is not commonly elevated in intestinal TB, as TB primarily involves infection with a specific pathogen rather than widespread inflammatory changes in the bowel.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Both intestinal tuberculosis (TB) and Crohn's disease can show granulomatous inflammation on biopsy, making this a common finding rather than an exception.

 

Option B: Diarrhea is often an early symptom in both conditions due to inflammation, ulceration and disruption of normal bowel function.

 

Option C: While perianal disease characterized by multiple fistulae in ano is more commonly associated with Crohn's disease, it may occasionally be seen in intestinal TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

c-ASCA and fecal calprotectin is typically elevated in inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn's disease and not in intestinal TB.

 

Similarities between Intestinal TB and Crohn’s:

 

  • Affect terminal ileum commonly

  • Characterized by ulcers

  • Granulomatous inflammation is seen

  • Can affect any part of GIT

  • Stricture, perforation and fistulation seen

  • Presentation is diarrhea or intestinal obstruction

  • Similar findings on contrast imaging: String sign, Sterlin sign

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1328-29

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with abdominal pain and mild diarrhoea. A tender mass is palpable in the right iliac fossa. Intermittent fever, anaemia and weight loss were also found. On resection of a part of the ileum, the following "cobble-stone" appearance was seen. What is your most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Crohn’s disease

 

Option D:

 

The above specimen depicts typical “cobblestone” appearance of terminal ileum illustrating longitudinal ulceration and cobblestone mucosa.

 

Chronic inflammatory disease of the ileum with skip lesions is Crohn's disease.

 

Crohn's disease is known for its transmural inflammation, skip lesions, and cobblestone appearance due to longitudinal ulcerations and mucosal edema.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Intestinal TB can mimic Crohn's disease but usually presents with systemic symptoms of tuberculosis and features like night sweats and a positive tuberculosis test.

 

Option B: Polyposis syndromes typically present with multiple polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract, not with the cobblestone appearance seen in Crohn's.

 

Option C: Diverticulitis does not typically present with the "cobblestone" mucosa characteristic of Crohn's disease. It commonly affects sigmoid colon and not terminal ileum.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Crohn's is a chronic inflammatory condition with a pathognomonic feature of non-caseating granulomas and may require a combination of medical and surgical treatments based on severity and complications. Characteristic "cobblestone" mucosa and longitudinal ulcerations on an intestinal resection are indicative of Crohn's disease.

 

Etiology: Genetic + environmental factors (smoking, hygiene hypothesis, M paratuberculosis bacteria).

 

Salient Features:

Can affect any part of GI from mouth to Anus, typical site is terminal ileum.

1. Cut section:

  • Ulcers

  • Skip lesions with normal mucosa in the middle (cobblestone)

 

2. Microscopy:

  • Microscopically focal areas of chronic inflammation involving all layers of the intestinal wall with lymphoid aggregates are characteristic of CD. Non-caseating giant cell granulomas found in 60% of patients are pathognomonic of CD. They are most commonly seen in anorectal disease.

 

3. Clinical features:

  • Diarrhea

  • Pain

  • Bleeding

 

4. Extra intestinal manifestations: Uveitis, Arthropathy

 

5. Diagnosis: c-ASCA andfecal calprotectin elevated + CECT abdomen/Colonoscopy with biopsy

 

Treatment:

  • Medical: acute exacerbation: steroids

  • Chronic: start with sulfasalazine –immunosuppressants: anti TNF agents

  • Surgery: resection in presence of stricture and disconnect the enterocutaneous fistula if present.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with bleeding in his stools and right iliac fossa pain. USG abdomen is normal. Barium meal follow-through findings are as shown. What is the treatment of the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wedge resection

 

Option B:

 

The image shows Meckel’s diverticulum.

 

Wedge resection, or more specifically, Meckel’s diverticulectomy, is the treatment of choice if the diverticulum is causing symptoms or complications like bleeding, as in this case.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: IV antibiotics would be indicated for an infectious process, which is less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.

 

Option C: Mikulicz strictureplasty is a surgical procedure used in Crohn's disease to address strictures without removing sections of the intestine, not typically used for Meckel's diverticulum.

 

Option D: Resection and anastomosis is a more extensive surgery that might be indicated if there were complications like perforation or in broad based Meckel’s diverticulum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meckel's diverticulum is a potential cause of gastrointestinal bleeding in children and typically requires surgical intervention with a diverticulectomy or wedge resection of the affected area.

 

Note: When found in the course of abdominal surgery, a Meckel's diverticulum can safely be left alone, provided it has a wide mouth and is not thickened. When there is doubt, it can be resected.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed Pg. 1311- 1312

questions.text: During diagnostic laparoscopy for chronic abdominal pain, small bowel was noted to have findings as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crohn’s disease

 

Option B:

 

The image shows “creeping fat” mesentery seen in Crohn’s disease.

 

Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory condition of the gastrointestinal tract, characterized by transmural inflammation, which can cause a range of symptoms including abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss.

 

The image shows a creeping fat pattern on the mesentery, which is a classic feature of Crohn's disease, along with bowel wall thickening and narrowing of the lumen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. TB: Tuberculosis can affect the gastrointestinal tract and may mimic Crohn's disease; however, the presence of creeping fat is more characteristic of Crohn's.

 

Option C. Diverticulitis: Diverticulitis typically affects the sigmoid colon and is characterized by the presence of inflamed diverticula, not the small bowel changes seen in the image.

 

Option D. Ulcerative colitis: Ulcerative colitis is limited to the colon and rectum and is characterized by continuous, superficial inflammation of the colonic mucosa, not the transmural, segmental inflammation seen in Crohn's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creeping fat, thickened bowel walls, and narrowing of the lumen are indicative of Crohn's disease and help distinguish it from other conditions like tuberculosis, diverticulitis, and ulcerative colitis.

 

  • The terminal ileum is the most commonly affected segment of bowel in patients with CD, often occurring in combination with other areas of disease. More proximal small bowel is less frequently involved.

  • Colitis alone occurs in up to one-third of cases, the stomach and duodenum are affected in around 5% of cases, but perianal lesions are common, affecting up to 50% of patients. Perianal disease occurs in 25% of patients with small bowel disease and in 75% of patients with Crohn’s colitis.

  • Macroscopically CD is characterized by fibrotic thickening of the intestinal wall with narrowing (structuring) of the lumen and fat wrapping (encroachment of mesenteric fat around the bowel).

  • There is usually a dilated bowel just proximal to the stricture and deep mucosal ulcerations with linear or serpiginous (snake-like) patterns in the stricture area itself. Oedema between ulcers gives rise to a characteristic cobblestone appearance of the mucosa.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1327.

choices.text: Primary sclerosing cholangitis is a common extra-intestinal manifestation
Montreal classification is used in patients with Crohn’s for disease manifestation
Surgery will not cure CD
Perianal CD is typically characterized by abscess

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about Crohn’s disease (CD)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary sclerosing cholangitis is a common extra-intestinal manifestation

 

Option A:

 

Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is indeed associated with inflammatory bowel disease, but it is less commonly seen in Crohn's disease than in Ulcerative Colitis (UC). Thus, stating that PSC is a "common" extra-intestinal manifestation in CD is incorrect.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: The Montreal classification is utilized for Crohn's disease to categorize the disease based on the age at diagnosis, the behavior of the disease, and its anatomical location. This classification aids in understanding the patient's disease course and in making therapeutic decisions.

 

Option C: Surgery for CD is not curative and is typically reserved for managing complications such as strictures, fistulas, or abscesses since CD is a chronic condition with the potential for relapse and reoccurrence after surgery.

 

Option D: Perianal disease in CD commonly presents with abscess formation, which may lead to complex fistulae, requiring both medical and sometimes surgical management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While surgery is an important tool for managing complications of CD, it is not a curative treatment due to the chronic and relapsing nature of the disease.

 

  • The extraintestinal manifestations of CD are similar to those that occur in UC. Primary sclerosing cholangitis is relatively rare in CD, compared with UC. Gallstones are common, as an inflamed or absent (because of resection) terminal ileum leads to reduced absorption of bile salts. Amyloidosis is common but is rarely symptomatic.

  • Each patient with CD should have their disease phenotype (manifestations) classified according to the Montreal classification. This is important as it allows an overview of disease progression in the individual patient over time, and enables group comparisons and evaluations. The Montreal classification specifies age at diagnosis, behaviour and disease location.

  • Perianal CD is distressing and often debilitating for patients. The most common presentation is with a perianal abscess: perianal swelling, redness and pain, followed by discharge of pus or fecal drainage to perianal skin or vagina, implying fistulae.

  • Surgical resection will not cure CD. Surgery, therefore, focuses on managing the complications of the disease. The fundamental principle is to preserve a healthy gut and to maintain adequate function. Intestinal resection should be kept to the minimum required to treat the local consequences of disease to mitigate against the potential for short bowel syndrome.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1329-31

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with a history of travel for a trek complained of fever and abdominal discomfort 1 week after returning. She was observed to have splenomegaly and leukopenia by her clinician. In the course of the disease, she had an acute abdominal event and died. Which of the following is the likely finding in the autopsy to suggest a typhoid ulcer perforation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Longitudinal ulcers

 

Option B:

 

From the clinical scenario described in the question, it is evident that it is enteric fever (typhoid), which presents with longitudinal ulcers.

 

The clinical features presented in this scenario—a history of travel, fever, abdominal discomfort, splenomegaly, leukopenia, and an acute abdominal event leading to death—are suggestive of a systemic infection like typhoid fever. Enteric fever often results in characteristic longitudinal ulcers, which are most commonly located in the distal ileum.

 

Longitudinal ulcers along the axis of the gut are characteristic of typhoid fever, which is consistent with the clinical scenario described.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Transverse ulcers are not typical of typhoid fever and are more commonly associated with conditions like inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease) or TB.

 

Option C: Pin-point ulcers are not typical of typhoid fever but may be seen in conditions like ischemic colitis.

 

Option D: Pseudopolyps are associated with inflammatory bowel diseases, such as ulcerative colitis, and are not a feature of typhoid fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation and complications of typhoid fever, including the presence of longitudinal ulcers that may lead to life-threatening complications such as intestinal perforation.

 

  • Typhoid fever is caused by Salmonella and presents with fever and abdominal pain after an incubation period of 10–20 days. Over the next week, the patient can develop distension, diarrhoea, splenomegaly and characteristic ‘rose spots’ on the abdomen caused by a vasculitis.

  • Typhoid is a systemic infection and diagnosis of typhoid is confirmed by culture of blood or stool. Treatment is by antibiotics, usually chloramphenicol.

  • Many surgical complications can result, including paralytic ileus, intestinal hemorrhage, free ileal perforation and cholecystitis.

  • Invasion of the systemic circulation, which is a characteristic feature of salmonellosis, may cause severe Gram-negative sepsis, resulting in septic shock.

  • Some patients develop metastatic sepsis, including septic arthritis and osteomyelitis, meningitis, encephalitis, disseminated intravascular coagulation and pancreatitis.

  • Perforation of a typhoid ulcer characteristically occurs during the third week of the illness, although it is sometimes the first clinical sign of the disease. The ulcer is parallel to the long axis of the gut and is usually situated in the distal ileum. Perforation requires surgery to wash out and close the ulcer and intestinal resection is usually avoided.

  • Diagnosis of bowel perforation secondary to typhoid:

  1. The patient presents in, or has recently visited, an endemic area.

  2. The patient has persistent high temperature and is very toxic.

  3. Positive blood or stool cultures for Salmonella typhi.

  4. After the second week, signs of peritonitis usually denote perforation, which is confirmed by the presence of free gas seen on a radiograph.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1308

questions.text: Most common location of Carcinoids from the below sites is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Appendix

 

Explanation

 

Carcinoid tumors are a type of neuroendocrine tumor that can be found throughout the body. They are most commonly located in the gastrointestinal tract, but they can also occur in the lungs and other sites. The appendix is indeed the most common location for carcinoid tumors, which is consistent with the answer provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Distribution of Carcinoid tumours:

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Table 57.6

choices.text: Midgut carcinoids are the most common NETs
Chronic abdominal pain is the most frequent initial symptom.
Chromogranin A is the most specific marker for the diagnosis of carcinoid
Only patients without distant metastases are potential candidates for curative surgery of the primary tumor

questions.text: All of the following statements about carcinoid tumors are true except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromogranin A is the most specific marker for diagnosis of carcinoid

 

Option C:

 

Chromogranin A is often elevated (non-specific) and elevated 24-hour urinary 5-HIAA is specific for diagnosis.

 

While Chromogranin A is often elevated in patients with carcinoid tumors, it is not highly specific and can be elevated in various other conditions. The most specific marker for the diagnosis of carcinoid tumors is elevated urinary 5-HIAA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: This is correct. Midgut carcinoids are indeed the most common type of NETs, and they typically present later in life.

 

Option B: This is correct. Chronic abdominal pain is often the first symptom that prompts further investigation leading to the diagnosis of a carcinoid tumor.

 

Option D: This is correct. Patients without distant metastases are potential candidates for curative surgery, which can include resection of the primary tumor and regional lymph nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromogranin A can be elevated in carcinoid tumors, it is not the most specific marker; instead, urinary 5-HIAA levels are more specific for the diagnosis.

 

  • Midgut carcinoids are the most common NETs with a peak age of diagnosis at 60–70 years. They are the second most common small bowel malignancy.
  • They arise from the enterochromaffin cells and secrete serotonin and substance P. They are either solitary or multiple (30%)
  • Chronic abdominal pain is the most frequent initial symptom. The carcinoid syndrome is seen in 20–30% of patients with liver metastases.
  • Up to 20% of patients are diagnosed during the investigation of liver metastases or they may be incidentally found during surgery for another reason (laparotomy or appendicectomy).
  • Cross-sectional CT or MRI often shows the mesenteric lymph nodes with a characteristic spiraling of vessels trapped in the desmoplastic reaction
  • In the search for a primary tumour, CT and/or MRI is followed by 68Ga-DOTATOC PET, fused with CT.
  • Biopsy is diagnostic and Ki-67 grading is an important prognostic factor
  • Patients without distant metastases (stages I–III) are all potential candidates for curative surgery of the primary tumour and regional nodal metastases.
  • Concomitant cholecystectomy should be considered owing to the risk of gallstone formation secondary to Somatostatin analogues (SSAs).
  • In the presence of stage IV (metastatic disease) surgery is contemplated when the patient has obstructive symptoms (palliative) or if an R0 resection (curative) can be achieved with concomitant liver metastasectomy. In this setting, patients should have preoperative protection with intravenous SSAs to avoid a carcinoid crisis.
  • Medically, SSAs are an effective treatment for syndrome control for functional NET’s.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 910-911

questions.text: Tuberculosis can affect any part of the body, and also affects the small intestine, mainly at the ileo-cecal junction. Treatment involves the use of anti-tubercular drugs, and surgery is seldom done. In which of the following cases will you do surgery for ileocecal TB?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute obstruction                

 

Explanation

 

  • A course of anti-tuberculous chemotherapy usually leads to cure, provided the pulmonary tuberculosis is adequately treated. Surgery is usually undertaken only in the rare event of a perforation or complete intestinal obstruction.

  • Other scenarios such as ulceration, mass (hyperplastic cecal TB) or frequent diarrhoea are also medically managed.

                                               

Educational objective:

 

If the patient has features of subacute intermittent obstruction, bowel resection, in the form of limited ileocolic resection with anastomosis between the terminal ileum and ascending colon for ileocolic hyperplastic disease, strictureplasty for single ileal stricture, bowel resection for multiple closely placed strictures or right hemicolectomy for extensive ileocolic disease precluding limited resection, is performed as deemed appropriate. 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 89, 1308

questions.text: Identify the mismatch about CD and Ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

Option B:

 

 

  • Perianal disease is typically seen in CD and not in UC.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Table 75.1

choices.text: It is associated with an increased risk of colorectal cancer.
The condition is characterized by the presence of neoplastic polyps predominantly in the colon.
It is linked with an increased risk of various other gastrointestinal and extraintestinal malignancies, including pancreatic cancer.
It is related to a mutation in the STK11 gene on chromosome 19.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with a family history of autosomal dominant gastrointestinal polyps presents for evaluation due to noticing dark freckle-like spots inside her mouth and on her lips, which she reports having since childhood. She also mentions intermittent episodes of abdominal pain and occasional blood-streaked stools. On examination, numerous pigmented macules are noted on her lips, oral mucosa, and fingers. Colonoscopy reveals multiple polyps in her colon. Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding the syndrome this patient most likely has?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The condition is characterized by the presence of neoplastic polyps predominantly in the colon.

 

Option B:

 

Above shown condition is Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS).

 

While PJS is characterized by hamartomatous polyps, these polyps are not neoplastic (i.e., not cancerous) in nature, but they can lead to complications such as intussusception.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: This is a true statement; patients with PJS have an increased lifetime risk of colorectal cancer. Despite the increased risk of malignancy in general, malignant change in the polyps themselves is uncommon.

 

Option C: True, PJS is associated with an increased risk for several types of cancer, including pancreatic cancer.

 

Option D: True, a mutation in the STK11 gene is associated with PJS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical features and genetic associations of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, include the polyps are hamartomatous rather than neoplastic.

 

  • This is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by melanosis of the mouth and lips, with multiple hamartomatous (benign tumour-like malformations resulting from faulty development in an organ) polyps in the small bowel and colon.

  • Mutation of the STK11 gene on chromosome 19 has been found in a proportion of patients.  The risk of pancreatic adenocarcinoma is significant.

  • Regular colonic surveillance should be performed and female patients should attend breast and cervical screening.

  • Despite the increased risk of malignancy in general, malignant change in the polyps themselves is uncommon.

  • Resection may be indicated, however, for heavy and persistent or recurrent bleeding or intussusception. Polyps may be removed by enterotomy (snared via a colonoscope introduced via an enterotomy) or, by laparotomy. Heavily involved segments of the small intestine may occasionally be resected.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg. 1309

choices.text: Most commonly results due to a leak from anastomosis
Fistula of > 500ml effluent/day outputs usually heal spontaneously
Nutritional support and skin protection form important constituents of management
Contrast studies are done to define fistula length for reconstruction

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement concerning entero-cutaneous fistulae?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fistulas of > 500ml effluent/day outputs usually heal spontaneously

 

Option B:

 

Low output fistulas of < 500ml effluent/day heal spontaneously. The majority of low-output fistula can be expected to heal spontaneously, provided there is no distal obstruction or disease at the fistula site. 

 

This is the incorrect statement. Fistulas with high output (>500ml/day) are less likely to heal spontaneously and typically require intervention.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: True, enterocutaneous fistulas often result from leaks at surgical anastomosis sites.

 

Option C: True, nutritional support and skin protection are vital components of enterocutaneous fistula management to optimize healing and prevent complications.

 

Option D: True, contrast studies such as fistulography or computed tomography (CT) are commonly used to define the anatomy and length of the fistula for surgical planning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low output fistulas of <500ml effluent/day heal spontaneously.

 

Principles Of Management of Enterocutaneous Fistulae (SNAP):

 

S: Elimination of Sepsis and Skin protection


N: Nutrition – A period of Parenteral Nutrition may well Be required


A: Anatomical Assessment

 

P: Definitive Planned surgery

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed.  pg 1315-16

choices.text: Plasma neuro- specific enolase

questions.text: Carcinoid tumor is diagnosed by which of the following marker?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urinary 5-HIAA

 

Option A:

 

The diagnosis of carcinoid syndrome relies on measurement of urinary or plasma serotonin or its metabolites in the urine. The measurement of 5-HIAA is used most frequently. Platelet serotonin levels are more sensitive than urinary 5-HIAA but are not generally available.

 

The diagnosis of carcinoid tumors often involves measuring urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), a metabolite of serotonin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Serum chromogranin A levels may be elevated in carcinoid tumors, but it is not typically used for diagnosis.

 

Option C: Plasma neuro-specific enolase levels may be elevated in certain neuroendocrine tumors, but it is not specific for carcinoid tumors.

 

Option D: Urinary 5-hydroxytryptophan (5-HTP) levels are not commonly used in the diagnosis of carcinoid tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of carcinoid tumors often involves measuring urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), a metabolite of serotonin.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg. 910-911

questions.text: All are features of carcinoid syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mitral regurgitation

 

Option A:

 

Tricuspid regurgitation and right sided heart abnormalities are a feature of carcinoid syndrome.

 

Mitral regurgitation is not typically associated with carcinoid syndrome. Instead, tricuspid regurgitation and right-sided heart abnormalities are characteristic features.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Asthmatic attacks can occur in carcinoid syndrome due to bronchoconstriction and airway inflammation.

 

Option C: Reddish-blue cyanosis is a common presentation in carcinoid syndrome, often resulting from flushing and peripheral vasoconstriction.

 

Option D: Diarrhea is a hallmark symptom of carcinoid syndrome, typically resulting from the release of serotonin and other vasoactive substances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tricuspid regurgitation and not mitral regurgitation are a feature of carcinoid syndrome.
  • The clinical syndrome itself consists of reddish-blue cyanosis, flushing attacks, diarrhoea, borborygmi, asthmatic attacks and, eventually, pulmonary and tricuspid stenosis. Classically, the flushing attacks are induced by alcohol.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1310

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient presented to the OPD with bouts of abdominal pain and mild diarrhea. On examination, a tender mass was felt at the right iliac fossa. The following radiograph was obtained. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crohn’s disease

 

Option B:

 

The above scenario and the barium meal follow through image show ileal stricture known as “String sign of Kantor” which is seen in Crohn’s disease or ileocecal TB.

 

Crohn’s disease can present with recurrent abdominal pain, diarrhea, and a tender mass in the right iliac fossa, often indicative of a localized inflammatory process or abscess formation. The radiograph may reveal findings such as bowel wall thickening and strictures, as shown in the image.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Ulcerative colitis typically presents with diffuse colonic inflammation and features such as bloody diarrhea, rectal urgency, and tenesmus. It does not commonly manifest with a tender mass in the right iliac fossa.

 

Option C: Paralytic ileus is characterized by non-mechanical obstruction of the bowel due to impaired peristalsis, typically seen after abdominal surgery or in response to metabolic disturbances. It does not typically present with a palpable mass in the right iliac fossa.

 

Option D: Mesenteric ischemia presents with severe abdominal pain out of proportion to physical examination findings, often accompanied by systemic symptoms such as fever and leucocytosis. It does not commonly present with a palpable mass in the right iliac fossa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Crohn's disease commonly presents with recurrent abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss.
  • Magnetic resonance enterography (oral contrast) or enteroclysis (contrast administered via nasoduodenal tube) is particularly effective at demonstrating small bowel stricturing, including the string sign of Kantor. String of Kantor is not diagnostic of Crohn’s since it is non-specific, it is also seen in Ileocecal TB.

 

Ref: Pg 1330 Bailey and Love, 28th Ed.
